e470410858b4.description: Keeping literature a vital part of popular culture.
e470410858b4.name: Electric Literature
e470410858b4.shortDescription: Keeping literature a vital part of popular culture.

paragraphs.text: Was Star Wars improved by midichlorians and trade negotiations?
paragraphs.name: b399

paragraphs.text: At the same time, the appeal to “realistic” portrayal of alien or magical beings doesn’t have anything to do with realism. Magical creatures don’t exist! If aliens exist, we don’t know what they are like yet! Human history doesn’t illuminate the history of fictional creatures. It’s quite possible that an alien race might have a monoculture, and the creatures of actual mythology and folklore were often portrayed simplistically. The call to make make such races more complex is not to make them more “true” to the reality of dragons, Martians, or giant eagles. It is a call to make them more human, and thus more interesting to human readers.
paragraphs.name: 0e4d

paragraphs.text: In contrast to “worldbuilding,” I’ll offer the term “worldconjuring.” Worldconjuring does not attempt to construct a scale model in the reader’s bedroom. Worldconjuring uses hints and literary magic to create the illusion of a world, with the reader working to fill in the gaps. Worldbuilding imposes, worldconjuring collaborates.

And for all the worldbuilding love that The Lord of the Rings gets, Tolkien’s work would fail the worldbuilding guides I’ve linked to here. He may have set the table for high fantasy, but he doesn’t even pass contemporary fantasy author Brandon Sanderson’s first “law’ of magic. The focus on worldbuilding has moved far beyond simply creating some interesting backstories and complex politics to increase the drama of the tale, to expecting a writer to have mapped out every detail of a world as if they were producing an encyclopedia instead of a story. Would the mythic The Lord of the Rings be improved by more discussion of elvish trade agreements and Mordor dining room etiquette?
paragraphs.name: 36dc

paragraphs.text: The problem I see with worldbuilding is that readers have come to expect books to meet a standard that the author can’t possibly (and probably isn’t trying to) meet. When I’ve taught fiction classes, I’ve often seen that when students encounter a book outside of the modes of actual realism or faux worldbuilding realism, they don’t know how to evaluate it. They believe that a different way of seeing reality aren’t invitations to see reality in a new way yourself, but simply failures of worldbuilding.
paragraphs.name: aba5

paragraphs.text: Even in epic fantasy stories, though, it’s questionable how much detailed worldbuilding improves a work. Tolkien is revered among worldbuilding obsessives for going to such lengths as inventing complete languages for his fictional races before even writing the story. Contrast that with George R. R. Martin, who famously describes himself as a “gardener” instead of an “architect,” and who simply makes up some fake words and lets the reader infer the rest. Readers may prefer one series to the other for a variety of reasons, but I doubt one reader in a million prefers The Lord of the Rings because dwarven has more realistic grammar than Dothraki.
paragraphs.name: ed24

paragraphs.text: And for all the worldbuilding love that The Lord of the Rings gets, Tolkien’s work would fail the worldbuilding guides I’ve linked to here. He may have set the table for high fantasy, but he doesn’t even pass contemporary fantasy author Brandon Sanderson’s first “law’ of magic. The focus on worldbuilding has moved far beyond simply creating some interesting backstories and complex politics to increase the drama of the tale, to expecting a writer to have mapped out every detail of a world as if they were producing an encyclopedia instead of a story. Would the mythic The Lord of the Rings be improved by more discussion of elvish trade agreements and Mordor dining room etiquette?
paragraphs.name: 36dc

5c9d205b6302.title: Hi Lincoln, maybe another reason readers expect worldbuilding nowadays is because modern TV series…

paragraphs.text: Hi Lincoln, maybe another reason readers expect worldbuilding nowadays is because modern TV series need worldbuilding to create a sense of plausibility and a lot of people can work about this (researchers, set designers etc.) while a writer is alone and she/he needs to concentrate about the story they want to write.
paragraphs.name: 080b

510080713138.title: I am old, practically senile, and easily bored.

paragraphs.text: I am old, practically senile, and easily bored.

Without getting into all the philosophy (which I never understood) I am an empiricist. The physical world as best we can understand it through empirical science actually exists. Art, for lack of a better term) tickles our nervous system. If we like it, it’s good. If we don’t…

fb46f82a7e6a.title: Fantastic point: worldconjuring requires any detail to bend to the purposes of the plot, which just…

paragraphs.text: Fantastic point: worldconjuring requires any detail to bend to the purposes of the plot, which just good writing. It’s easy to do everything BUT writing — reading how to’s, world building, reading ABOUT world building, etc., while the book or story languishes unbuilt.

paragraphs.text: When writing a story set in the contemporary world a writer doesn’t give the history of the New World before arriving at the point where Sally picks up her cup of coffee. You create the material the reader needs to set up a frame and the specific items/details needed to tell the story. The rest the reader fills in. That’s obvious. What doesn’t seem…

Each story needs its own level of worldbuilding, be it minimalistic or intense. Different…

Also, he describes himself as more of an architect writer-type and would probably only advise people to not overdo worldbuilding for entirely…

adbd17bd3517.title: I like the fact that you threw Middle Earth in there, because when it started out, he didn’t do any…

paragraphs.text: I like the fact that you threw Middle Earth in there, because when it started out, he didn’t do any worldbuilding or conjuring. He set out to write about the horrors of war and the evils of modernization. The world was shaped as he wrote. I remember reading about a letter he’d written to someone (font remember who now) about arriving where his heroes…
paragraphs.name: 6b1d

c07fc9374d16.title: World building is basically the method acting of the writing world.

paragraphs.text: World building is basically the method acting of the writing world. For some authors it can be immensely helpful, but for others its a distraction or a hindrance. Explicit world building a tool and should be viewed merely as such and not the end all, be all of particular genre’s of speculative fiction.
paragraphs.name: 49f0

d2c3d276c111.title: I think the idea of worldbuilding as method acting is a good one, although my focus here was not…

paragraphs.text: I think the idea of worldbuilding as method acting is a good one, although my focus here was not really on the process of planning or pre-writing as much as the process of reading and evaluating literature. The amount of worldbuiding that goes into pre-writing can be quite different than the amount of worldbuilding that actually makes it on the page.

virtuals.subtitle: I do think that whatever works for a writer is, well, whatever works. If worldbuilding helps a writer in the planning or editing stages…

content.subtitle: I do think that whatever works for a writer is, well, whatever works. If worldbuilding helps a writer in the planning or editing stages…
